## 개요 React components implement a `render()` method that takes input data and returns what to display. This example uses an XML-like syntax called JSX. Input data that is passed into the component can be accessed by `render()` via `this.props`. ```tsx title="layout.tsx class HelloMessage extends React.Component { render() { return
Hello {this.props.name}
; } } root.render(); ``` ## Declarative React makes it painless to create interactive UIs. Design simple views for each state in your application, and React will efficiently update and render just the right components when your data changes. A paragraph with _emphasis_ and **strong importance**. > A block quote with ~strikethrough~ and a URL: https://reactjs.org. - Lists - [ ] todo - [x] done ## Component-Based Build encapsulated components that manage their own state, then compose them to make complex UIs. Since component logic is written in JavaScript instead of templates, you can easily pass rich data through your app and keep state out of the DOM. ## Learn Once, Write Anywhere We don’t make assumptions about the rest of your technology stack, so you can develop new features in React without rewriting existing code. React can also render on the server using Node and power mobile apps using React Native. ![React Office desk](https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1633356122102-3fe601e05bd2?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&ixid=MnwxMjA3fDB8MHxwaG90by1wYWdlfHx8fGVufDB8fHx8&auto=format&fit=crop&w=2070&q=80) > The most important addition in React 18 is something we hope you never have to think about: concurrency. We think this is largely true for application developers, though the story may be a bit more complicated for library maintainers. Concurrency is not a feature, per se. It’s a new behind-the-scenes mechanism that enables React to prepare multiple versions of your UI at the same time. You can think of concurrency as an implementation detail — it’s valuable because of the features that it unlocks. React uses sophisticated techniques in its internal implementation, like priority queues and multiple buffering. But you won’t see those concepts anywhere in our public APIs. When we design APIs, we try to hide implementation details from developers. As a React developer, you focus on what you want the user experience to look like, and React handles how to deliver that experience. So we don’t expect React developers to know how concurrency works under the hood. However, Concurrent React is more important than a typical implementation detail — it’s a foundational update to React’s core rendering model. So while it’s not super important to know how concurrency works, it may be worth knowing what it is at a high level. A key property of Concurrent React is that rendering is interruptible. When you first upgrade to React 18, before adding any concurrent features, updates are rendered the same as in previous versions of React — in a single, uninterrupted, synchronous transaction. With synchronous rendering, once an update starts rendering, nothing can interrupt it until the user can see the result on screen. In a concurrent render, this is not always the case. React may start rendering an update, pause in the middle, then continue later. It may even abandon an in-progress render altogether. React guarantees that the UI will appear consistent even if a render is interrupted. To do this, it waits to perform DOM mutations until the end, once the entire tree has been evaluated. With this capability, React can prepare new screens in the background without blocking the main thread. This means the UI can respond immediately to user input even if it’s in the middle of a large rendering task, creating a fluid user experience. Another example is reusable state. Concurrent React can remove sections of the UI from the screen, then add them back later while reusing the previous state. For example, when a user tabs away from a screen and back, React should be able to restore the previous screen in the same state it was in before. In an upcoming minor, we’re planning to add a new component called `` that implements this pattern. Similarly, you’ll be able to use Offscreen to prepare new UI in the background so that it’s ready before the user reveals it. Concurrent rendering is a powerful new tool in React and most of our new features are built to take advantage of it, including Suspense, transitions, and streaming server rendering. But React 18 is just the beginning of what we aim to build on this new foundation.

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"The most important addition in React 18 is something we hope you never have to think about: concurrency. We think this is largely true for application developers, though the story may be a bit more complicated for library maintainers."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:48,columnNumber:3},this),`
`]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:48,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"Concurrency is not a feature, per se. It\u2019s a new behind-the-scenes mechanism that enables React to prepare multiple versions of your UI at the same time. You can think of concurrency as an implementation detail \u2014 it\u2019s valuable because of the features that it unlocks. React uses sophisticated techniques in its internal implementation, like priority queues and multiple buffering. But you won\u2019t see those concepts anywhere in our public APIs."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:50,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"When we design APIs, we try to hide implementation details from developers. As a React developer, you focus on what you want the user experience to look like, and React handles how to deliver that experience. So we don\u2019t expect React developers to know how concurrency works under the hood."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:52,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"However, Concurrent React is more important than a typical implementation detail \u2014 it\u2019s a foundational update to React\u2019s core rendering model. So while it\u2019s not super important to know how concurrency works, it may be worth knowing what it is at a high level."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:54,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"A key property of Concurrent React is that rendering is interruptible. When you first upgrade to React 18, before adding any concurrent features, updates are rendered the same as in previous versions of React \u2014 in a single, uninterrupted, synchronous transaction. With synchronous rendering, once an update starts rendering, nothing can interrupt it until the user can see the result on screen."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:56,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"In a concurrent render, this is not always the case. React may start rendering an update, pause in the middle, then continue later. It may even abandon an in-progress render altogether. React guarantees that the UI will appear consistent even if a render is interrupted. To do this, it waits to perform DOM mutations until the end, once the entire tree has been evaluated. With this capability, React can prepare new screens in the background without blocking the main thread. This means the UI can respond immediately to user input even if it\u2019s in the middle of a large rendering task, creating a fluid user experience."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:58,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:["Another example is reusable state. Concurrent React can remove sections of the UI from the screen, then add them back later while reusing the previous state. For example, when a user tabs away from a screen and back, React should be able to restore the previous screen in the same state it was in before. In an upcoming minor, we\u2019re planning to add a new component called ",(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.code,{children:"<Offscreen>"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:60,columnNumber:373},this)," that implements this pattern. Similarly, you\u2019ll be able to use Offscreen to prepare new UI in the background so that it\u2019s ready before the user reveals it."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:60,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"Concurrent rendering is a powerful new tool in React and most of our new features are built to take advantage of it, including Suspense, transitions, and streaming server rendering. But React 18 is just the beginning of what we aim to build on this new foundation."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:62,columnNumber:1},this)]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx",lineNumber:1,columnNumber:1},this)}function _r(l={}){let{wrapper:r}=l.components||{};return r?(0,n.jsxDEV)(r,Object.assign({},l,{children:(0,n.jsxDEV)(je,l,void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx"},this)}),void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-b2cdcabd-0048-46bd-84e2-4999c231c41f.mdx"},this):je(l)}var hr=_r;return pr(Nr);})();

body.raw: ## 메타 태그란? 메타 태그(meta tag)는 웹페이지가 담고 있는 컨텐츠가 아닌, **웹페이지 자체의 정보**를 명시하는 목적으로 사용되는 HTML태그 입니다. 이러한 웹페이지의 메타 정보는 주로 HTML의 `` 요소를 통해 마크업을 하고, HTML 문서 내에서 `` 요소 내부에 배치되므로 일반 유저가 보게되는 웹페이지의 컨텐츠에는 아무런 영향을 주지 않습니다. 하지만 검색엔진과 같은 기계들이 웹페이지를 읽을때 메타 태그의 내용들이 서비스에서 어떻게 표시될지를 결정하는 핵심요소가 됩니다. ### 정리 - 태그는 웹페이지 자체의 정보인 메타데이터를 정의할때 사용됨. - 태그는 언제나 요소 내부에 위치해야함. 위치는 앞뒤 상관없지만, 태그 앞쪽에 위치해야함. - 브라우저와 검색 엔진을 사용할 수 있도록 웹 문서의 정보를 포함하기 때문에 SEO(검색엔진 최적화)와 관련이 깊음. ## 속성 메타 태그는 `http-equiv` `name` `content` 3가지 속성이 있습니다. #### http-equiv - http-equiv ="항목명" - 웹 브라우저 서버에 명령을 내리는 속성 - name 속성을 대신해 사용 가능 - html 문서가 응답 헤더와 웹 서버로부터 웹 브라우저에 전송됫을때만 의미를 가짐 - content 속성의 점보, 값을 위한 HTTP header를 제공 - html4에서는 문자 설정을 할때 사용했지만, html5에서는 문자 설정 방법이 더욱 간단해짐 ```jsx ``` #### name - 몇가지의 meta 정보의 이름을 정할 수 있으며, 지정하지 않으면 http-equiv 와 같은 기능 #### content - meta 정보의 내용을 저장 - name 속성과 http-equiv와 연관된 값을 줌 ## 사용법 회사의 코드를 참고하여 대표적으로 사용되는 종류만 정리했습니다. 이외 더욱 많은 종류가 있고, 필요에 따라 구글링하여 사용하면 됩니다. #### 검색 엔진을 위한 키워드(keywords)를 정의 ```jsx ``` #### 웹 페이지에 대한 설명(description)을 정의 ```jsx ``` #### 문서의 저자(author)를 정의 ```jsx ``` #### 5초 뒤에 다른 페이지로 리다이렉트(redirect) ```jsx ``` #### 모든 장치에서 웹 사이트가 잘 보이도록 뷰포트(viewport)를 설정 ```jsx ``` --- ### 참고 - https://www.daleseo.com/html-meta-tags-for-seo/ - https://tcpschool.com/html-tags/meta - https://inpa.tistory.com/entry/HTML-📚-meta-태그-정리

`,(0,n.jsxDEV)(r.p,{children:"This is in contrast to today's more common concurrency model, in which OS threads are employed. Thread-based networking is relatively inefficient and very difficult to use. Furthermore, users of Node.js are free from worries of dead-locking the process, since there are no locks. Almost no function in Node.js directly performs I/O, so the process never blocks except when the I/O is performed using synchronous methods of Node.js standard library. Because nothing blocks, scalable systems are very reasonable to develop in Node.js."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/River/Desktop/2023/Project/river-dev/posts/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-d936c22b-f1fc-4808-b9e9-02537aea2646.mdx",lineNumber:29,columnNumber:1},this),`

body.raw: ## 개요 Next의 13버전이 출시되면서 기존의 `page` 디렉터리와 유사한 기능인 `app` 디렉터리가 추가되었습니다. use server > 서버 액션을 정의하기 위해선 `use server` 지시어를 추가해야 합니다. 이때 인라인으로 함수 내부 최상단에 작성하거나, 별개의 파일로 액션을 분리해 파일 최상단에 작성할 수 있습니다. - [프로젝트 저장소](https://github.com/yujiseok/jobkok) - [노션](https://www.notion.so/3-e6ecfb1d3143440f9afa58481929ab5a) plugins: [ 'gatsby-plugin-mdx', ]

body.raw: ## 발생 원인 객체가 비어있을 수 있는데 해당 객체의 내부 메서드를 사용하거나, 내부 객체 키에 값을 넣어주려고 할 때 발생합니다. 쉽게 말해서 객체가 'null'일 수 있다는 뜻이고, 이럴 경우를 대비해주면 됩니다. ## 예시 코드를 보면 `const file = event.target.files[0];` 부분에서 에러가 발생합니다. ```tsx const onChangeFileUpload = (event: ChangeEvent) => { const maxSize = 5 * 1024 * 1024; const file = event.target.files[0]; // Object is possibly 'null'.ts(2531) 오류 ... }; ``` ## 해결방법 해결방법은 여러가지가 있습니다. ### 1\. if문 제가 현업에서 가장 많이 사용하는 방법입니다. 누구나 쉽게 이해할 수 있고 가독성이 좋기 때문입니다. 다만 리서칭을 해보니 `if문`을 사용하면 매번 같은 케이스에 계속 `if문`을 사용해야하니 가장 좋지 않은 방법이라고 합니다. 하지만 개인적인 생각으로는 팀의 코드 스타일과 규칙에 따르면되지 않을까 싶습니다. 밑에서 이야기할 `옵셔널 체이닝`과 `타입단언 방식`도 물론 자주 사용했지만, 다양한 오류가 발생하는 경험이 많았습니다. 특히 백엔드 팀원들과 소통이 원활하지 못하다면 `if문`을 적극 추천합니다. ```tsx const onChangeFileUpload = (event: ChangeEvent) => { const maxSize = 5 * 1024 * 1024; if (!event.target.files) return; // file이 없는 경우 return const file = event.target.files[0]; ... }; ``` ### 2\. 옵셔널체이닝(optional chaining) 옵셔널체이닝`?`은 객체 내의 `key`에 접근할 때 그 참조가 유효한지 아닌지 직접 명시하지 않고도 접근할 수 있는 연산자입니다. `?.` 앞의 평가대상이 만약 `nullish(undefined 혹은 null)`일 경우 평가를 멈추고 `undefined`를 반환합니다. 쉽게 말해서 앞에 대상의 값이 있는지 없는지 체크해주고, 없으면 `undefined` 던져준다 생각하면 됩니다. ```tsx const students = { mark: { age: 20, score: { korean: 90, english: 80, math: 40, }, }, john: { age: 20, }, }; console.log(students.mark.score.english); // 80; console.log(students.john.score.english); // TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'english') console.log(students.john?.score?.english); // undefined ``` #### 주의할점 옵셔널체이닝은 존재하지 않아도 괜찮은 대상에만 적용해야합니다. 단순히 에러를 피하기 위해 남용하다가 디버깅이 어려워질 수 있습니다. 매우X1000000 중요한 내용입니다. 회사에서 저와 같은 주니어개발자들이 마감기간의 부담감과 압박을 느끼면 일단 만들자라는 마인드로 무분별하게 남용하는 코드들이 생길 수 있는데, 대표적으로 옵셔널체이닝이라고 생각합니다. 다행히(?) 저는 그렇지 않았지만 다른 팀원의 물음표 남발로 배포 직전에 힘들었던 기억이 있습니다... 만약 `user` 객체가 무조건 꼭 있어야 하는데, 그 안의 `info`의 `age`는 필수값이 아니라면 아래와 같이 작성해야합니다. ```tsx console.log(user?.info?.age); -> user 객체가 꼭 있어야할 필요가 없다는 뜻입니다. console.log(user.info?.age); -> user 객체가 없다면 에러를 뱉을 것입니다. ``` ### 3\. 타입 단언(type assertion) `!`를 사용하거나 `as`를 사용합니다. (효과는 동일합니다.) 타입 단언이란 타입스크립트가 추론하지 못하는 타입을 개발자가 직접 명시해주는 문법입니다. #### as ```tsx let someValue: unknown = 'this is a string'; let strLength: number = (someValue as string).length; console.log(someValue); // 'this is a string' console.log(strLength); // 16 ``` #### ! ```tsx interface nameObject { firstName: string; lastName: string | null; } let obj: nameObject = { firstName: 'Kang', lastName: null, }; // 'obj.lastName' is possibly 'null'.ts(18047) // lastName 키의 값이 string이나 null이 들어올수 있지만 // 만일 위와 같이 null이 들어와 버리면 toString을 실행할수 없기에 tsc 컴파일러가 미리 경고를 띄워준다. console.log(obj.lastName.toString()); ``` 타입 가드나 조건문을 쓰지않고 간단하게 `!`로 해결이 가능합니다만, 정말 `!`는 손모가지 걸고 사용해야하기 때문에 확신이 없다면 그냥 조건문 사용합시다..! ```tsx console.log(obj.lastName!.toString()); ``` --- ### 참고 - https://ko.javascript.info/optional-chaining - https://coding-farmer.tistory.com/4 - https://kyounghwan01.github.io/blog/TS/object-null/ - https://abangpa1ace.tistory.com/256 - https://timmousk.com/blog/typescript-object-is-possibly-null/ - https://developer.mozilla.org/ko/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Optional_chaining
